awd_titl_txt: Workshop: STS research on Africa and from Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will highlight and address the structural challenges faced by STS scholars and their scholarship from, on, and about the continent of Africa. The conference will contribute to increasing knowledge in the field by bringing together the disparate communities of scholarship on African STS, integrating insights from studying Biomedicine, the Environment and Information and Communication Technologies.  By increasing participation of uniquely African perspectives in the creation of STS knowledge about the continent, the workshop will deepen our insights on various processes of science, technology and innovation on the African continent.

The core question of the workshop is this: What are the boundaries of Science and Technology in Africa and how should we recognize and address both the uniqueness of African knowledge production and innovation on the one hand, and the potential that STS work in Africa has to offer to the field as a whole on the other? By bringing together a diverse group of STS scholars who work in and on the African continent before the Society for Social Studies of Science (4S) meeting, the workshop will create the institutional pressure for the society to more fully engage with African STS scholarship. The workshop will also affect the field as a whole by generating new scholarly agendas to expand the visibility of STS research in and on Africa.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Workshop: STS Africa brought together over fifty scholars of STS and the African continent to Sydney, Australia for a two-day meeting. A significant intellectual merit was that the workshop acted to bridge the disparate communities of STS scholarship on the African continent around the themes of Biotechnology, Information and Communication Technologies, and the Environment. These communities of African STS scholarship had, in their unique ways, addressed the question of the limits of the boundaries of Science and Technology in Africa and how such boundaries should be recognized. By creating a shared space for intellectual exchange, the workshop allowed the various scholars in attendance to learn more about the similarities and differences in their approach to STS scholarship on the African continent.

The workshop was held at the John Woolley Building of the University of Sydney from August 28 – 29. There was a significant representation of junior and senior scholars, and scholars from the African continent as well as the United States, Europe, and Australia. Academic publishers were also represented, as MIT press and the editor of a major STS journal spoke to workshop participants about possible avenues for publishing their work.

A significant broader impact resulting from the workshop was that we were able to disseminate the discussion and the theoretical cross-fertilization by presenting research papers, over the following three days at the yearly Society for Social Studies of Science (4s) meeting in Sydney which held right afterward. A substantial number of workshop participants gave papers at the 4S meeting across three panels focused on Information Technology, Biomedicine, and Infrastructure reflecting the core themes of the NSF sponsored workshop.
